attributes.description:
Chinese, Made for the export market
Collected by Ann Allen Dorr Ives
Presented to the Museum by daughter Hope Brown Russell

This large Chinese Export bowl features a panoramic view of the “hongs”—the office, warehouse, and living spaces for foreign merchants in Canton, China in the late 18th-century. Here European and American merchants traded with their Chinese counterparts for highly desirable teas, silks, and porcelains. 

*Click on the dots to see how the bowl is associated with each place, and view related images.
attributes.title: Hong Bowl (ca. 1790-1800)

attributes.description: The Chinese produced bowls like this in the town of Jingdezhen in southern China specifically for the western market. Undecorated, they were carried 500 miles overland to Canton, where enamel decoration was applied in workshops close to the hongs.
attributes.title: Production area

attributes.description: Mary Okill presented Hong Bowl to Anne Allen Ives in 1842. It is unclear where Okill received the bowl from. However, Okill is a member of the prominent Jay family with ties to the China trade. Peter Jay, her grandfather, was a wealthy merchant in New York, and her uncle, James Jay, had been responsible for selecting the supercargo for the Empress of China.
attributes.title: Mary Okill (1786-1859)

attributes.description:
Hong Bowl (1790-1802)




Gifted by H. F. Lenfest to the Washington and Lee's ceramics collection, which spans over 4,000 years of human history. The collection includes ceramics from Asia, Europe and America, and is especially rich in Chinese export porcelain made for the American and European markets between 1600 and 1900.

http://www.wlu.edu/x34692.xml
attributes.address: 204 West Washington Street, Washington and Lee University, Lexington, VA 24450, USA
attributes.title: Washington and Lee University Reeves Collection

attributes.description:
Bowl (Punch or Hong bowl) (1780-1790)

Originating from Jingdezhen, China, and donated by  Henry Francis du Pont to the museum. 

http://museumcollection.winterthur.org/
attributes.title: Winterthur Museum (1960)

attributes.description:
Hong Bowl (1785 - 1795)
The Smithsonian Institution acquired a similar bowl in 1961 from dealer Herbert Schiffer. Once it came to the Smithsonian, conservators performed a radical restoration, referring to very similar hong bowls held in collections at the Henry Francis du Pont Winterthur Museum in Delaware, and the Reeves Collection at Washington and Lee University in Lexington, Virginia.

http://americanhistory.si.edu/collections/search/object/nmah_587576
attributes.address: Constitution Avenue Northwest, Washington, DC 20530, USA
attributes.title: National Museum of American History (1961)

attributes.description:
Punch Bowl (1786-1788)

In 2008 the National Trust purchased a rare eighteenth century Chinese punch bowl with a provenance from Nostell Priory, West Yorkshire. It is decorated with a depiction of the western trading posts on the waterfront at Canton (Guanghzhou).

Patricia Ferguson, who has researched this bowl, dates it to either 1786 or 1788. This is based on a comparison between the national flags shown on the bowl and dated records and pictures of the trading activities in Canton. The bowl appears in an 1806 inventory of Nostell Priory, but it is not known how it was originally acquired – the Winn family of Nostell Priory had no links with the China trade. Patricia Ferguson makes the amusing suggestion that Sir Rowland Winn, sixth Baronet (1775-1805), who was a keen fox hunter, may have won the bowl as a prize for winning a horse race.

http://nttreasurehunt.wordpress.com/category/chinese-export-wares/
attributes.title: National Trust (2008)

attributes.description:
The bowl was presented to the Museum by daughter of Ann Allen Dorr Ives, Hope Brown Russell, in 1909. It is now placed across from the dining room in Pendleton House. 
This large Chinese Export bowl features a panoramic view of the “hongs”—the office, warehouse, and living spaces for foreign merchants in Canton, China in the late 18th-century. Here European and American merchants traded with their Chinese counterparts for highly desirable teas, silks, and porcelains.
attributes.title: RISD Museum (1909)

attributes.description: Anne Allen Ives, pioneer collector of ceramics in Providence, acquired the bowl from Mary Okill. The specifics behind this exchange are unknown and somewhat puzzling, as Anne Ives preferred to collect ceramics with local histories. Ives was the daughter of Sullivan Dorr, one of the principal China trade merchants of the city and U.S. Vice Consul at Canton.She was also the wife of Moses Brown Ives, son of a business associate of Nicholas Brown II, a prominent merchant in Providence.
attributes.title: Anne Allen Ives (1810-1884)

attributes.description: The bowl identifies seven of the thirteen hongs, or places of business, the Chinese leased to foreigners in which they conducted their affairs while in the port of Canton or Guangzhou, China. This flag represents the place of the U.S. in this trading system.

attributes.title: Flags
Hongs in Canton
attributes.description:
On completion a large bowl like this was packed in a crate with several others and dispatched through the hongs. All goods for export were ferried in the small boats seen painted on this bowl, to the deep-water port of Whampoa further down the Pearl River.

Few Westerners would have seen any more of China than the small plot of land depicted on this bowl. In the 18th and early 19th centuries, the Chinese restricted foreign traders to the one port of Guangzhou. According to Samuel Shaw, the first American merchant to go to China, "Europeans, affter a dozen years' residence, have not seen more than what the first month presented to view."  

http://www.wlu.edu/prebuilt/arts/reeves/highlights/index.html
http://americanhistory.si.edu/collections/search/object/nmah_587576

attributes.title: Flags
attributes.description: The bowl identifies seven of the thirteen hongs, or places of business, the Chinese leased to foreigners in which they conducted their affairs while in the port of Canton or Guangzhou, China. This flag represents the place of Sweden in this trading system.
